childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 2006-2018

You were born the year Twitter launched with 140 characters and Pluto lost its planetary status. Both events are strangely relevant to your generation's relationship with brevity and existential demotion. George W. Bush was in the White House, still processing the Iraq War. Hurricane Katrina was fresh in national memory. The iPhone didn't exist yet—you'd have to wait a whole year for that.

Your childhood happened during the Great Recession, though you were too young to understand why the adults seemed stressed. You were two when Lehman Brothers collapsed and the economy cratered. By the time you were aware enough to notice, things were just... like that. You didn't know the before times. You only knew austerity, job insecurity, and adults saying 'we can't afford that' more often than seemed normal.

Technology-wise, you never knew a world without YouTube. It launched just a year before you were born. By the time you were watching screens, streaming was already normal. You probably had an iPad before you had shoelaces you could tie yourself. Touchscreens felt intuitive because you literally grew up touching them.

You were seven during Sandy Hook. You don't remember a time before school shooting drills. Lockdowns weren't new—they were just how school worked. The anxiety of that became background noise, something you learned to live with because the alternative was too big to process.

Your childhood was documented on social media before you could consent to it. Your parents posted your milestones, your embarrassing moments, your whole life. You'll spend your twenties deciding how you feel about that.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen Z

You're Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012. That's the Pew Research definition, which means you're right in the middle of your generation—not the elder Gen Z who remembers flip phones, not the youngest who seem more like Gen Alpha. You're the median. The quintessential Gen Z experience is your experience.

Your generation is roughly 68 million people in the US, slightly smaller than Millennials but more diverse. You're the most racially and ethnically diverse generation in American history. You're also the most educated, the most connected, and—by most mental health metrics—the most anxious and depressed.

There's no single defining moment for Gen Z the way 9/11 was for Millennials. Instead, you have a constellation of traumas: school shootings that blur together, climate anxiety that started in elementary school, a pandemic that ate your adolescence. Your defining characteristic isn't a single event—it's perpetual crisis as a baseline.

You never expected the system to work for you. Millennials believed in institutions and were betrayed. You watched that betrayal and took notes. You're not disillusioned because you were never illusioned in the first place. That's either pragmatism or learned helplessness, depending on who you ask.

You're the first generation to grow up entirely in the smartphone era. You don't remember a time when you couldn't reach anyone instantly. Privacy is a concept you understand intellectually but have never actually experienced. Your childhood photos are on the internet forever.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Departed won Best Picture and Cars became Pixar's latest hit. High School Musical premiered on Disney Channel—a movie that would define the aesthetic of your early childhood even if you were too young to watch it in real-time. Daniel Craig became the new James Bond. 'Bad Day' by Daniel Powter was inescapable.

Musically, 2006 was peak mid-2000s pop-punk and emo. My Chemical Romance released The Black Parade. Fall Out Boy, Panic! at the Disco, and Paramore were unavoidable. This was music your older siblings and babysitters played, and it seeped into your consciousness. You'd rediscover it ironically in high school and then unironically love it.

TV in your childhood meant Nickelodeon and Disney Channel. iCarly, Hannah Montana, Wizards of Waverly Place. Drake & Josh, SpongeBob, Avatar: The Last Airbender. You grew up with content designed specifically for you, algorithmically optimized for engagement before you knew what algorithms were.

Your tween years collided with the rise of YouTube creators. You probably watched more PewDiePie, Smosh, and Markiplier than traditional TV. By high school, TikTok arrived and rewired your attention span entirely. You consume content in 15-second clips. Anything longer feels like a commitment.

The Marvel Cinematic Universe spans your entire conscious life. Iron Man came out when you were two. You've never known a world without superhero movies dominating the box office. Endgame happened when you were thirteen, which felt like the end of something important.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year Twitter launched with Jack Dorsey's first tweet: 'just setting up my twttr.' Google bought YouTube for $1.65 billion, which seemed insane at the time. The Nintendo Wii brought motion controls to gaming, and your family probably had one in the living room by the time you were old enough to hold a controller.

You were one year old when the iPhone launched. You don't remember the world before smartphones because you literally couldn't form memories yet. By the time you were aware of technology, touchscreens were just how things worked. The idea of a phone with physical buttons seems quaint, like rotary dials.

You were four when the iPad came out. You probably learned to swipe before you learned to write cursive—if you learned cursive at all. Your elementary school might have had iPads in the classroom. Your babysitter probably handed you one to keep you quiet.

You were six when Instagram launched. Ten when Snapchat went mainstream. Fourteen when TikTok took over. Your social media evolution wasn't Facebook → Instagram → TikTok. It was Instagram → Snapchat → TikTok, with Facebook being something your parents use.

COVID hit when you were thirteen or fourteen, right in the middle of high school. School went online. Socialization became Zoom calls and Discord servers. You learned that 'hybrid learning' meant nobody was learning anything. The technology that was supposed to connect you made you feel more isolated than ever.

Your relationship with technology is complicated in ways older generations don't understand. You know it's bad for you. You know it's designed to be addictive. You use it anyway because the alternative is being disconnected from everyone you know. That's not a choice—it's a hostage situation.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born the year Saddam Hussein was executed, which you learned about in history class as a thing that happened, not as news you experienced. The Iraq War was background noise for your entire childhood—something on the news that adults talked about but that didn't directly affect your daily life unless someone in your family was deployed.

You were two during the 2008 financial crisis. You don't remember it, but you lived its consequences. Your parents' anxiety about money, the friends whose families lost houses, the way 'the economy' became a vague boogeyman that explained why things cost more and there was less to go around. The recession shaped your childhood without you knowing it.

You were five when Osama bin Laden was killed. You probably remember the adults being excited, even if you didn't fully understand why. You were six when Sandy Hook happened. Twenty first-graders, kids your age. That was when school started feeling like a place where bad things could happen.

You were nine when marriage equality became law nationwide. By the time you were thinking about identity and relationships, LGBTQ+ rights were established, not aspirational. This seems obvious to you. It wasn't obvious to anyone who came before.

You were ten when Donald Trump announced his presidential campaign. Fourteen when the pandemic started. You watched the 2020 election, George Floyd protests, and the January 6th insurrection from whatever device you had. History was happening in real-time on your phone, sandwiched between TikToks and group chat memes.

You were eighteen when—well, we don't know yet. You're living through history right now, and it's probably exhausting. Your generation has experienced more 'unprecedented' events before turning twenty than previous generations experienced in a lifetime.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You're just entering the workforce now, and the landscape is unrecognizable from what career counselors described. Traditional career paths—college degree, entry-level job, climb the ladder—feel like advice from another century. The people telling you to 'pound the pavement' and 'get your foot in the door' haven't applied for a job since applications were on paper.

Your generation is pioneering the creator economy not as a side hustle but as a legitimate career path. You know people who make more from TikTok than their parents make at their jobs. You understand that attention is currency, that personal branding isn't optional, that being discoverable online is part of being employable.

You're entering a job market that's been reshaped by COVID. Remote work is normal. Hybrid schedules are expected. The five-day office week feels like a relic. But you also know that 'flexible' often means 'available 24/7' and 'work-life balance' is marketing copy, not policy.

You've watched Millennials burn out and decided that's not going to be you. Quiet quitting, act your wage, boundaries—these aren't laziness, they're survival strategies learned from watching the previous generation sacrifice everything for companies that laid them off anyway.

AI is reshaping every industry as you enter it. The skills you're learning might be automated before you're thirty. You're building careers on shifting ground, which isn't new—every generation faces change—but the pace of change is faster than anything before. Adaptability isn't a nice-to-have. It's the only thing that matters.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You've never known dating without apps. Tinder launched when you were seven. By the time you were interested in relationships, swiping was just how it worked. The idea of meeting someone organically—at a bookstore, through friends, at a party—sounds romantic but also statistically unlikely.

Your communication is primarily text-based, but it's layered in ways older generations don't understand. You know the difference between a 'haha,' a 'lol,' and a 'lmao.' You know that a period at the end of a text is passive-aggressive. You communicate through memes, voice notes, and reaction emojis. Actual phone calls feel aggressive.

You came of age during the pandemic, which means you missed formative social experiences. Proms were canceled. Graduations were Zoom calls. The parties, the awkward dances, the in-person rejection that teaches you resilience—you didn't get those. You got Animal Crossing and existential dread.

Your generation is dating less, having less sex, and partnering later than any previous generation. This isn't prudishness—it's a combination of economic precarity, mental health challenges, and having social needs partially met by online communities. Why risk rejection when you can find connection on Discord?

Friendships for your generation exist across platforms. You have friends you've never met in person who you talk to daily. The distinction between 'online friends' and 'real friends' feels outdated. Connection is connection. Geography is just logistics.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were a toddler during the 2008 financial crisis and a teenager during the COVID economic chaos. You've never experienced a stable economy. The idea of job security, affordable housing, and retirement sounds like something from a history book, not a realistic expectation.

Your financial worldview is shaped by scarcity you inherited but didn't create. You watched your parents struggle. You watched Millennials complain about student loans and housing prices. You took notes and decided that maybe the traditional path wasn't worth it. Gap years, trade schools, skipping college entirely—these aren't failures. They're rational responses to a rigged system.

You're surprisingly financially literate for your age, mostly because you had to be. TikTok and YouTube taught you about investing, budgeting, and side hustles before any adult thought to mention it. You know what index funds are. You understand compound interest. Whether you have any money to actually invest is a different question.

Crypto, meme stocks, NFTs—you were there for all of it. You watched people your age make millions and lose everything. You're skeptical of get-rich-quick schemes, but you also understand that slow-and-steady doesn't work when wages are stagnant and housing costs a million dollars.

Your generation isn't lazy about money—you're realistic. You've done the math on homeownership and know it doesn't add up. You've seen retirement calculators and laughed. You're not planning for a future that looks like your parents' future. You're planning for something different, whatever that turns out to be.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is that you've never known anything but crisis, which means you might not recognize when things are actually getting better. Your baseline is so skewed toward pessimism that good news feels like a trap. Optimism seems naive. Hope feels like something that will hurt you.

You're so terminally online that you sometimes mistake internet consensus for real-world consensus. The discourse on Twitter or TikTok isn't representative of what most people think. The loudest voices aren't the majority. But when you're chronically online, it's hard to remember that most people aren't.

Your generation struggles with sustained attention in ways that might limit what you can accomplish. You're used to content designed to capture you in seconds. Deep work—the kind that requires hours of uninterrupted focus—feels almost physically painful. This isn't a moral failing. It's what happens when your brain is trained on algorithms optimized for engagement.

You can be quick to cancel and slow to forgive. The impulse makes sense—you've watched institutions fail, leaders disappoint, and bad actors escape consequences. Holding people accountable matters. But the binary of canceled/acceptable doesn't leave room for growth, complexity, or context. Sometimes people are wrong without being irredeemable.

You're comfortable with digital activism but less comfortable with the slow, boring work of actual change. Posting is easy. Phone banking is hard. Sharing a petition feels productive. Showing up to a school board meeting doesn't. The dopamine hit of online engagement can substitute for the unsexy grind of real organizing.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your teens (2019-2024): Your teenage years were interrupted by a global pandemic. You spent formative years masked, distanced, and online. You missed milestones that every generation before you took for granted. You're already behind, through no fault of your own, and you'll spend your twenties catching up on social skills and experiences that should have happened naturally.

Your 20s (2026-2036): You're entering this decade now, or about to. This is when you'll figure out who you are outside of school, outside of your parents' home, outside of the structures that have defined you so far. The job market is weird. Housing is impossible. Dating is apps. You'll probably change careers multiple times. You'll definitely question everything you were told about how life is supposed to work. That questioning is healthy. The old script doesn't apply.

Your 30s (2036-2046): By now, you'll have established something—a career, a community, maybe a family. Or you'll have deliberately opted out of those things, and that's fine too. You'll be managing the fallout of climate change, which will have stopped being abstract and started being logistical. Where can you afford to live that isn't flooding, burning, or freezing? These will be real questions. You'll be old enough to have perspective on what your generation accomplished and what it failed to accomplish. Both lists will be long.

Your 40s (2046-2056): You'll be mid-career, maybe peak career, in an economy that looks nothing like today's. AI will have reshaped work in ways we can't predict. You might be managing AI systems. You might be competing with them. You'll be the 'senior' person in rooms full of Gen Alpha and Gen Beta, who will think your references are ancient. You'll be parenting teenagers, if you have kids, and trying to navigate technology that makes TikTok look quaint.

Your 50s and beyond (2056+): Retirement as a concept may not exist by then, or it might look completely different. You'll have lived through multiple 'once-in-a-lifetime' crises before hitting this decade. You'll tell younger people about the pandemic, the political chaos, the climate tipping points. They'll think of it like you think of the Cold War—something that shaped a generation but feels historical. You'll be adapting, because that's what you've always done. Adaptation isn't a strategy for your generation. It's a survival skill baked in from birth.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 4.3 million people born in 2006. The entire Gen Z population is about 68 million in the US, making you slightly smaller than Millennials but the most diverse generation in American history.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more pragmatic and less idealistic. Millennials believed in institutions and were disappointed. You never believed in the first place. They graduated into one recession; you're graduating into whatever this is. They remember life before smartphones; you don't. They're burned out; you're burned out preemptively, having watched them sacrifice everything for nothing.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980), you're similar in cynicism but different in context. Gen X was the forgotten middle child between Boomers and Millennials. You're the overlooked younger sibling of Millennials. Gen X had latchkey childhoods and learned independence. You had helicopter parents and learned anxiety. They're running things now, for better or worse.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), the gap is almost incomprehensible. They grew up when college cost a summer job, houses cost a year's salary, and 'the future' was bright. You grew up when college costs a mortgage, houses cost a decade's salary, and 'the future' is something you're afraid of. The wealth they accumulated is not being passed down. The planet they inherited is not being preserved. You'll spend your life managing the consequences of their choices.

Compared to Gen Alpha (born 2013-2025), you're the experienced older sibling. You remember the transition to smartphones. They don't. You remember the pandemic happening. They'll just know the world after. You're the last generation to remember any version of 'before.' That makes you a bridge—the translators between the analog past and the digital future.

Your mental health statistics are alarming. Rates of anxiety, depression, and suicidal ideation are higher than any previous generation at the same age. This isn't weakness—it's what happens when you grow up with constant access to global trauma, comparison through social media, and a future that looks increasingly apocalyptic. You're coping with more than any generation should have to, with fewer resources than they had.
